After creating different components, the program doesn’t actually do anything. If you click a button or enter something into a text-field, nothing will happen. That’s because you didn’t tell the computer what to do. In order to make the program interactive, you need an action listener (to monitor if an action happened, e.g a button is clicked) and an event handler (to tell the program to do something, e.g. update a label).

In order to do it, we need to create a new class to handle things. You can create a private class called ButtonHandler (as it will handle the button we created) inside GUIExample.

What we want to do is that entering something in textfield and clicking button will let echo show anything you entered plus “ Eh?”. You could also change anotherLb to “Echoed”.

You may notice that there is an error for ButtonHandler, as you did not have the required method in your class when you implement ActionListener. We’ll add actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) to the class. As you may use a handler for multiple objects, it’s a good idea to specify the source of the event.

If you run the program and click button, there will be nothing changed. In the last post, we created a simple and empty window. In this post, we’ll talk about how to add other components into the window.

Known how to set up a window, we can add components (such as buttons, labels, password fields) into the frame. First, we can add a label saying “hello, world”.

Run it and you’ll find that the window shows “hello, world” vertically-centering and horizontally-left. If you create another label and add it to the window like this:

an interesting thing happened: “hello, world” is replaced by “just another label”. There are lots of instances that you would not want that. The reason for this is that there is no layout in the frame; Java doesn’t know where to place them. Thus, we need add a layout. The simplest layout is flow-layout. Like its name, it just put components side by side. Add this layout:

Voil√†. Two labels are side by side now; you may not want the labels like that, we’ll explore other layouts later. Try to resize your window and see what happened with labels. While you are resizing the window, the arrangement and position of label is changing and messing up your design. To avoid this, we can set the window unresizable.

Graphic User Interface (GUI) has more fun than console (somebody thinks so). In Java, we can use Swing, a native library for GUI, to create a GUI application instead of an application only interacting with console.

For Swing, the most basic GUI element is a frame. Basically, the frame is the window showed in your desktop containing other elements like buttons, labels and many things you see in Java applications. We will talk about how to create a simple frame in this tutorial.

ELA 20-1 Brave New World Background Info.
entry.content:
Background Information

Technology Development with Utopia and Dystopia

When Huxley wrote Brave New World, the Western society has completed industrialization and colonized many regions in the World with new weapon technologies. In 1920s and 1930s, huge development in technologies such as television, more wider radio system and mass production of cars and planes also caused the raising of consumerism. People were enjoying variety of entertainment and spend money on industrial products. In this context, people were looking forward a utopia.

A utopia is an ideal society that provides

all the needs for people. Technology advancement fulfills people‚Äôs needs of matter. Narcotic drugs are also found and used as ‚Äúhappiness pill‚Äù to fulfill mental needs. People at that time thought that an ideal world was coming without pain, disease, etc. as Huxley describes in the novel. The World State is a state that all people are ‚Äútruly‚Äù happy in the exchange of freedom. The state has very advanced technology including mass production of human, harmless drug. The babies are treated in a special facility. All human are trained from the born that they are good and happy, they are glad about their caste. For the purpose of running the state, the castes are used to give different people different rules and abilities.

In that ‚Äúideal‚Äù society, however, is not actually ideal. Huxley builds the ‚Äúideal‚Äù society to prove utopia is dystopia. A dystopia is a extremely bad society. In the World State, people are without any freedom. All the happiness is taught by the state. People are no longer real people. Huxley believes that technological advancement not necessarily leads to an ideal society but a society without real people.

Historical References related to Soviet Union in Chapter I to VI

In Brave New World, Huxley refers to many people and events happened at his time including Henry Ford, Karl Marx, establishment of Soviet Union, etc. The people referred to are most the ones who represent an ideology. Due to the WWI and the Great Depression, the socialist/communist ideology was raising and the Russian Revolution caused a communist regime. There are many allusions made related to Soviet Union.

In the Chapter II, the allusions are made by describing the process of letting children hate books and flowers. The Director says the reason for hating flowers is that there will not be enough people working if they loves the nature. It is related to –°–°–°–† as the state encourages people to work for communism/state.

At the beginning of Chapter III, Polly Trotsky is referring to Leon Trotsky who was one of the leaders of Soviet Union but was exiled because he was against Stalin‚Äôs dictatorship. That the Director asks P. Trotsky out is a symbol for the exile of L. Trotsky and that L. Trotsky created the Fourth International for his own Trotskyism. The Director represents –°–°–°–†, a totalitarian state just as the World State.

As well in the Chapter III, the Controller express the detriment of home, family, parents, etc. The Controller express the same propaganda as the Soviet Union that all people should work for the state in order to achieve social stability and give up self for the whole good. The hates of liberalism, (English) democracy and religion for the good of the state (everyone) are also identical to –°–°–°–†.

As the first thinker of communism, Karl Marx is called Bernard Marx. Bernard is possibly referred to George Bernard Shaw who advocated for women rights. In the novel, Marx is from the Bureau of Psychology as Marx is the philosopher/ideologist who directs the development of –°–°–°–† at first. The events of talking between Lenina (Vladimir Lenin) and Marx represent Marxism-Leninism, the Lenin‚Äôs understanding of Marxist communism. As Bernard is a feminist, he feels bad about Lenina who is used as a tool of the state (that Stalin used Lenin to achieve dictatorship). As well, Lenina does not understand Marx even they believe the ‚Äúsame‚Äù state showing that the revision of Marxism communism which is a totalitarian ideology developed further by Stalin.

entry.title: Atheros AR8161L Gigabit Ethernet Controller Driver for Fedora 17
entry.content:
Absolutely delete M$ Losedows 8 and install Fedora 17.

However…Fedora 17 does not have driver of the network card.

So I need to find the driver.

At last, solve it with the compat-wireless 2.6.

First, install the kernel-headers, kernel, and gcc from dvd/cd.

Second, download the compat-wireless (before 2012-05-10, after this date it seems the compate wireless not support AR8161) in another computer and use USB disk to copy it to fedora 17.

The link: http://linuxwireless.org/download/compat-wireless-2.6/compat-wireless-2012-05-09-pc.tar.bz2

Third, uncompress and install the driver.
